text: in America's Southwest a desert
landscape stretches to the horizon and
contains the fossilized remains of long
extinct creatures and a discovery that
maybe the common ancestor to all mammals
this is the Chinle formation and its
geological history goes back more than
200 million years within its rock layers
are evidence of dinosaurs and mammals
competing here millions of years ago in
this arid landscape the fossil of the
earliest known mammal
was brought to light by paleontologist
Adrian hunt
he has spent years studying long extinct
animals that once roamed these lands and
beneath the red earth he made the find
of a lifetime less than half an inch
long it places mammals on earth over 200
million years ago this is the oldest
known mammal fossil the skull of a dello
Basilius you can tell from this tiny
skull that the living animal was no
bigger than a mouse but this tiny skull
was the starting point for all mammals
including of course humans like us della
Basilius was a very small little mammal
the size of a shrew or a mouse we think
that it lived mainly by eating insects
just from it the kind of teeth that we
think it had it may even have come out
at night it may have lived in holes in
the ground a small animal like that
spends a lot of time avoiding all the
big animals around it
